by the [[Shenzhen Government]].SIDA is the member of [[International Council of Societies of Industrial Design]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Shenzhen Company Profiles|url=http://www.cbbc.org/cbbc/media/cbbc_media/events/documents/shenzhen-company-profiles.pdf|work=cbbc.org}}</ref>.
Till April 2017,SIDA has taken in 821 member units from Shenzhen and across the country, including institutions that provide services for industrial design chains and the relevant organizations,such as,[[manufacturer]]s,marketing institutions,etc. ==Subsidiaries== *Shenzhen Institute for Innovation Design<ref>{{cite news|title= Shenzhen maker week to kick off friday |url= http://english.sz.gov.cn/ln/201709/t20170911_8653714.htm |work= sz.gov.cn }}</ref> *Sino-Finnish Design Park<ref>{{cite news|title=Sino-Finnish Design Park promotes design and technology |url= http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/culture/2015-05/18/content_20741231.htm |work= chinadaily.com }}</ref> *Shenzhen Open Innovation Lab<ref>{{cite news|title=We visited the world’s amazing gadget market|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/12/13/13936394/huaqiangbei-electronics-market-shenzhen-china-gadget|work= theverge.com }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Shenzhen Company Profiles|url=http://www.cbbc.org/cbbc/media/cbbc_media/events/documents/shenzhen-company-profiles.pdf|work=cbbc.org}}</ref> *Industrial Design Public Service Platform ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category: 2008 establishments in China]] [[Category:Business organizations based in China]] [[Category: Organizations based in Shenzhen]] [[Category: Organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:Art and design organizations]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Siobhán Daly | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | other_names = | occupation = Producer
Artistic Director | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Siobhán Daly''' is a British producer and artistic director. ==Education== Daly is a graduate of [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art|Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA)]], [[King's College London]] and [[Goldsmiths College, University of London]].{{cite web|title=Siobhán Daly|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2987050/|website=IMDb}} She attended [[St Edmund's College, Ware|St Edmund's College]] boarding school in [[Ware, Hertfordshire]] known for being the oldest post-[[Reformation]] Catholic school in the UK.{{cite web|title=St Edmund's College, Ware|url=http://www.stedmundscollege.org/|website=St Edmund's College}} She is the granddaughter of [[Edward Daly (Mayor)|Mayor Edward Daly]].{{cite web|title=Siobhan Daly website|website=www.siobhandaly.com}} ==Career== ===Theatre=== As Associate Producer at the [[West End theatre|West End]] [[Theatre Royal Haymarket]], Daly oversaw the expansion and development of the production company, TRH Productions, including the world premiere of [[Fatal Attraction (play)|Fatal Attraction]] alongside producer [[Robert Fox producer|Robert Fox]].{{cite web|title=Fatal Attraction|url=http://www.trh.co.uk/season/fatal-attraction/|website=Theatre Royal Haymarket Productions}} Directed by [[Sir Trevor Nunn]] and adapted by [[James Dearden]], the production starred [[Natascha McElhone]], [[Kristin Davis]] and Mark Bazeley.{{cite web|title=Fatal Attraction|url=http://www.trh.co.uk/season/fatal-attraction/|website=Theatre Royal Haymarket Productions}} Daly actively championed young talent and was a member of the panel for the Masterclass ''Pitch Your Play'' initiative in 2013, allowing emerging writers the opportunity to workshop their play and perform on the theatre's stage.{{cite web|title=Pitch Your Play|url=http://www.masterclass.org.uk/pitch-your-play/|website=Masterclass}} She was also a member of ''Ask an Expert'' at TheatreCraft in 2013, held at the Royal Opera House and launched by director [[Jamie Lloyd (director)|Jamie Lloyd]].{{cite web|title=More than 1000 young people aged 16–25 attended this year's TheatreCraft event!|url=http://www.trh.co.uk/news/more-than-1000-young-people-aged-16-25-attended-this-years-theatrecraft-event/|website=Theatre Royal Haymarket}} Daly is the Artistic Director and Executive Producer of [[Grassroots Shakespeare London]], the multi [[Off West End]] Award nominated company which she established in 2011.{{cite news|title=Doing Without a Director – That's Grassroots Shakespeare's Choice|url=http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/features/doing-without-a-director-t-57|agency=British Theatre Guide}} In January 2016, Grassroots were announced as the first ever resident theatre company at the Leicester Square Theatre, making them the first resident Shakespeare company in the West End since the [[Royal Shakespeare Company|RSC]] and the only permanent resident Shakespeare company in the West End.{{Cite web|title = Grassroots Shakespeare London takes residency at Leicester Square Theatre {{!}} News {{!}} The Stage|url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2016/grassroots-shakespeare-london-takes-residency-at-leicester-square-theatre/|website = The Stage|access-date =23 January 2016}} Their production of [[Twelfth Night]] starred [[Ellie Nunn]] in her West End Shakespeare debut as Viola and [[John Pickard (British actor)|John Pickard]] as [[Sir Toby Belch]], and was performed as part of Shakespeare 400 in April - May 2016.{{Cite web|title = Grassroots Shakespeare London takes residency at Leicester Square Theatre {{!}} News {{!}} The Stage|url = https://www.thestage.co.uk/news/2016/grassroots-shakespeare-london-takes-residency-at-leicester-square-theatre/|website = The Stage|access-date = 23 January 2016}} As part of this, Daly produced a 14-hour live broadcast on Saturday 23 April 2016 in association with the live-stream app [[Periscope (app)|Periscope]], [[Twitter]] and [[GoPro]], with Grassroots' actors performing from 'Dawn til Dusk' in central London, including scenes at [[Middle Temple]], the location of the original performance of Twelfth Night.{{Cite web|url = https://blog.twitter.com/en-gb/2016/is-this-an-emoji-i-see-before-me-twitter-plays-its-part-in-shakespeare400|title = Is this an emoji I see before me? Twitter plays its part in #Shakespeare400 {{!}} Twitter Blogs|website = blog.twitter.com|access-date = 2016-05-21}} She subsequently oversaw Grassroots' actors performing speeches with [[Simon Russell Beale]] and a private view of the 1623 [[First Folio]], one of the top 5 editions remaining in the world.{{Cite web|url = http://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/Photo-Flash-Simon-Russell-Beale-Celebrates-Shakespeare-400-with-Grassroots-Shakespeare-at-Guildhall-20160511|title = Photo Flash: Simon Russell Beale Celebrates Shakespeare 400 with Grassroots Shakespeare at Guildhall|last = Desk|first = BWW News|website = BroadwayWorld.com|access-date = 2016-05-21}} The company performed at the Royal Shakespeare Company in [[Stratford-upon-Avon]] during the [[World Shakespeare Festival]]. In April 2014, Grassroots Shakespeare London celebrated [[Shakespeare]]'s 450th birthday as the only company performing his work during that period in London's West End with their sold-out production of [[Othello]] starring [[Ian Charleson Award]] nominee Nari Blair-Mangat as Othello{{cite web|url = https://www.londontheatre1.com/news/80242/review-of-othello-at-leicester-square-theatre/|title = Nari Blair-Mangat and James Alexandrou to star in Othello|website = London Theatre|last1 = Cheesman|first1 = Neil|accessdate = 17 February 2014}} and [[James Alexandrou]] as Iago{{cite web|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/news/eastenders-james-alexandrou-to-play-iago-in-shakespeares-othello-9214886.html|title = EastEnders' James Alexandrou to play Iago in Shakespeare's Othello|website = Independent|last1 = Denham|first1 = Jess|accessdate = 25 March 2014}} at the [[Leicester Square Theatre]]. On the birthday, the cast read sonnets with [[Damian Lewis]] at the [[London Guildhall]].{{cite news|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2611247/Damian-Lewis-praises-Shakespeare-marks-poets-450th-birthday.html|title = 'He was playful and versatile with words': Damian Lewis praises William Shakespeare as he reads the poet's first five sonnets at an event to mark his 450th birthday|date = 23 April 2014|publisher = Daily Mail}} The production featured on the [[BBC World Service]]'s ''The Why Factor'' programme.{{cite web|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01vzjrz|title = The Why Factor: Envy|website = BBC World Service}} Daly has worked at the [[Royal Opera House]] overseeing collaborations with [[The Royal Ballet]] and [[The Royal Opera]] on major projects, including the BP Big Screens live broadcasts into [[Trafalgar Square]] and throughout the UK, and the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC)'s Opening Ceremony for London's [[2012 Olympics]], executive produced by [[Wayne McGregor]] and starring [[Plácido Domingo]], [[Renée Fleming]], [[Bryn Terfel]], [[Paloma Faith]] and [[Kate Prince]]'s ZooNation.{{cite web|last1=Beard|first1=Matthew|title=London 2012 Olympics: Only the very best seats will do for the VVIPs flying in for Olympic opening show|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/olympics/olympic-news/london-2012-olympics-only-the-very-best-seats-will-do-for-the-vvips-flying-in-for-olympic-opening-show-7972910.html|website=Evening Standard|accessdate=24 July 2012}}{{cite web|title=Opening Ceremony of the 124th IOC Session|url=http://www.latimes.com/bal-afp-getty-14914158520120908180207-photo.html|website=Los Angeles Times}} Daly was identified as one of Britain's top young commercial producers by [[Society of London Theatre|SOLT]]/ [[UK Theatre|TMA]], one of only six people selected to train on their Stage One scheme in 2013. She worked, both touring and in the West End, with Edward Snape (The Stage Top 100 Producers 2012 & 2013){{cite web|title=The Stage 100 2013: the full list by category|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/2013/the-stage-100-2013-the-full-list-by-category/|website=The Stage}} on the [[Olivier Awards]] winning productions of [[Goodnight Mister Tom (play)|Goodnight Mister Tom]], [[The 39 Steps (play)|The 39 Steps]] and [[The Ladykillers (play)|The Ladykillers]]. She produced the 5 star, sell out [[Edinburgh Festival]] hit production of [[Manfred Karge]]'s Man to Man in 2015.{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/aug/08/man-to-man-review-edinburgh-festival-underbelly-potterow-margaret-ann-bain|title = Man to Man five-star review at Edinburgh festival – a world of shadows and shape-shifting|last = Lawson|first = Mark|date = 2015-08-08|website = the Guardian|access-date = 2016-05-21}} During the 2013–2014 season, Daly was a judge for the Olivier Awards, sitting on the Opera Panel. ===Film and TV=== Daly has worked extensively at the [[BBC]] including for BBC Drama Production on the long-running series [[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]] and alongside [[BAFTA]] winning drama producer and director Pier Wilkie,{{cite web|title=Television Drama Serial in 2009|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2009/television/drama-serial|website=BAFTA}} BBC Events on live outdoor broadcasts and in Commissioning for BBC Daytime. Productions for BBC Events included [[Live Earth]] at [[Wembley]] headlined by [[Madonna entertainer|Madonna]], working alongside [[Clarence House]] for the [[Concert for Diana]] at Wembley starring [[Elton John]], [[Children in Need]] appeal nights and major events such as [[The State Opening of Parliament]] and [[HM The Queen]]'s [[Royal Christmas Message|Christmas Broadcast]]. She was the Executive Producer on the short film, The Same Air,{{cite web|title=IMDb 'The Same Air'|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2261630/}} and has worked on numerous commercials and music videos for talent including [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]], [[Goldfrapp]], [[Kaiser Chiefs]], [[Dizzee Rascal]], [[Daniel Bedingfield]], [[Lily Allen]] and [[James Blunt]].{{cite web|title=Inspired By: Siobhán Daly, Theatre Producer|url=http://arcmagazine.co.uk/?p=197|website=Arc Magazine}} In 2015, she worked with [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Award]] winning director [[Daniel Mulloy]] on his new film 'Home'{{Citation|last = Mulloy|first = Daniel|title = Home|date = 2016-03-15|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5593606/?ref_=nm_flmg_dr_1|accessdate = 2016-05-21}} starring [[Jack O'Connell (actor)|Jack O'Connell]] and [[Holliday Grainger]]. The film premiered at [[South by Southwest|SXSW Film Festival]] and was nominated for the Grand Jury Award.{{Citation|last = Mulloy|first = Daniel|title = Home|date = 2016-03-15|url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5593606/awards?ref_=tt_awd|accessdate = 2016-05-21}} Daly has a background as an actor, having credits including [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s The Battle of Britain and performing in the 2011 [[Olivier Award]] winning production of [[La boheme|La bohème]] at the [[Soho Theatre]] in London.{{cite web|last1=Amer|first1=Matthew|title=La bohème Wins Best New Opera Production|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest-news/article/item115080/la-boheme-wins-best-new-opera-production/|website=Official London Theatre}} In 2016, Daly was jury selected by [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] to join BAFTA Crew, a scheme that identifies the UK's top emerging film and TV talent.{{Cite web|url = http://www.bafta.org/initiatives/supporting-talent/bafta-crew|title = BAFTA Crew|website = www.bafta.org|access-date = 2016-05-21}} ===Philanthropy=== Daly was the Chair of the [[English National Opera]] Young Patrons, supported in her role by Sir [[Peter Bazalgette]] during his tenure as Chair of the ENO, and the President, Sir [[Vernon Ellis]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.siobhandaly.com}} * {{IMDb name |id=2987050 |name=Siobhán Daly}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Daly, Siobhan}} [[Category:English theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware]] [[Category:BBC people]] [[Category:Royal Opera House]] [[Category:Alumni of Goldsmiths, University of London]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] [[Category:West End theatre]] [[Category:Alumni of King's College London]]

{{Infobox film | name = The Beguiled | image = The Beguiled (2017 film).png | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Sofia Coppola]] | producer = {{ubl|Youree Henley|Sofia Coppola}} | based on = {{based on|''A Painted Devil''|[[Thomas P. Cullinan]]}} | screenplay = Sofia Coppola | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Colin Farrell]] * [[Nicole Kidman]] * [[Kirsten Dunst]] * [[Elle Fanning]] }} | music = [[Phoenix (band)|Phoenix]] | cinematography = [[Philippe Le Sourd]] | editing = [[Sarah Flack]] | studio = {{ubl|[[American Zoetrope]]|[[FR Productions]]}} | distributor = [[Focus Features]] | released = {{Film date|2017|5|24|[[2017 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]|2017|6|23|United States}} | runtime = 94 minutes<ref name="pdf">{{cite web|url=http://affif-sitepublic-media-prod.s3-website-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/media_pdf/0001/53/78a5dd5bfbf16245a7385ff40f749cd6ac6293e2.pdf|title=2017 Screenings Guide|publisher=[[Cannes Film Festival]]|accessdate=May 11, 2017}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $10 million<ref>{{cite web | first=Anne | last=Thompson | title=With ‘The Beguiled,’ Sofia Coppola Seeks Cannes Redemption with a Southern-Gothic Remake | url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/05/the-beguiled-sofia-coppola-nicole-kidman-cannes-1201830554/ | work=[[IndieWire]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] | date=May 23, 2017 | accessdate=May 23, 2017}}</ref> | gross = $27.4 million<ref name=BOM>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=thebeguiled2017.htm|title=The Beguiled |publisher=[[IMDb]]|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> }} '''''The Beguiled''''' is a 2017 American [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Sofia Coppola]], based on the novel of the same name (originally published as ''A Painted Devil'') by [[Thomas P. Cullinan]]. It stars [[Colin Farrell]], [[Nicole Kidman]], [[Kirsten Dunst]], and [[Elle Fanning]].<!-- This film is not a remake; do not change the lede to say so. --> It is the second film adaptation of Cullinan's novel, following [[Don Siegel]]'s [[The Beguiled (1971 film)|1971 film of the same name]].
It premiered on May 24 at the [[2017 Cannes Film Festival]],<ref name="Nicole Kidman at The Beguiled World Premiere in Cannes">{{cite web|url=http://www.ikonlondonmagazine.com/nicole-kidman-at-the-beguiled-world-premiere-in-cannes | title= Nicole Kidman at The Beguiled World Premiere in Cannes | work=Ikon London Magazine | last1 = Orlova-Alvarez | first1 = Tamara| last2 = Alvarez | first2 = Joe | date=May 25, 2017 | accessdate=February 23, 2018}}</ref> and was selected to compete for the [[Palme d'Or]] in its main competition section,<ref name="Main a">{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/actualites/articles/the-2017-official-selection|title=The 2017 Official Selection|publisher=[[Cannes Film Festival]]|date=April 13, 2017|accessdate=April 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="IW">{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/04/cannes-2017-lineup-list-film-festival-schedule-1201804813/|title=2017 Cannes Film Festival Announces Lineup: Todd Haynes, Sofia Coppola, ‘Twin Peaks’ and More|work=[[IndieWire]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Graham|last=Winfrey|date=April 13, 2017|accessdate=April 13, 2017}}</ref> where Coppola won the [[Best Director Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Director]] award, becoming only the second woman to do so.<ref name="main-prizes">{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/festivals/cannes-film-festival-2017-award-winners-palme-d-or-1202446856/ |title=2017 Cannes Film Festival Award Winners Announced |first=Peter |last= Debruge |date=May 28, 2017 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Business Media]] |accessdate=August 27, 2018}}</ref> The film was released theatrically on June 23, 2017, by [[Focus Features]].
==Plot== Martha Farnsworth runs a [[single-sex education|girls school]] in [[Virginia]] during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. By 1864, almost all of the students, teachers, and slaves have left; only five students and one teacher, Edwina Morrow, remain. While out in the woods searching for mushrooms, Amy, a pupil, comes across John McBurney, a corporal in the [[Union Army]] who was wounded in the leg during battle, and has since [[Desertion|deserted]]. Amy brings McBurney to the school where he falls unconscious. The women lock McBurney in one of the rooms while Miss Farnsworth tends to his wounds. All the women and girls in the school are immediately fascinated by the handsome man.
Initially, some of the school's residents want McBurney to be delivered as a [[prisoner of war]] to the [[Confederate Army]], but Miss Farnsworth decides that they will let his leg heal before they decide what they will do with him. When Confederate soldiers arrive at the school, Miss Farnsworth does not tell them that a Union soldier is on the premises. While McBurney is recovering, the women and girls fight for his affection by giving him presents, wearing jewelery, and preparing a lavish dinner for him. He returns the affection, concentrating especially on Miss Morrow and Miss Farnsworth. When he is able to move again, he begins to help in the garden. It becomes clear that he fears returning to battle.
When Miss Farnsworth indicates that McBurney is healthy enough and will have to leave the school in a few days, he tries to convince her to let him stay as a gardener, and tells Miss Morrow that he has fallen in love with her. One night, he tells Miss Morrow to await him in her room. When he does not appear and she hears strange noises, she investigates and finds him in bed with Alicia, a teenage pupil. McBurney tries to calm Miss Morrow down, but she pushes him away, causing him to fall down the stairs and badly break his already injured leg. Miss Farnsworth decides that the only way to stop him from dying is to amputate the leg.
When he awakes the next day and realizes he has lost his leg, McBurney is devastated and furious, accusing the women (and especially Miss Farnsworth) of having punished him for not choosing their rooms instead of Alicia's. He is locked up in his room but threatens Alicia, who gets him the room key. He then breaks out, steals a gun, and threatens the women before storming off. Miss Morrow follows him to his room, where they have passionate sex.
Meanwhile Miss Farnsworth tries to find a solution. One of the students suggests killing McBurney by preparing him a dinner of [[Mushroom poisoning|poisonous mushrooms]], to which Miss Farnsworth agrees. During the dinner, Miss Morrow, who is not informed of the plan, is deterred by the others at the last minute from putting the mushrooms on her own plate. McBurney's suspicions are not aroused; he eats the mushrooms. Seconds later, he falls to the floor, in the throes of death. While the others are sewing McBurney's body into a [[shroud]], Miss Morrow looks on, devastated. The film ends with the women dragging McBurney's body to the road so that he will be found by the next Confederate soldiers who pass by.
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Colin Farrell]] as Corporal John McBurney * [[Nicole Kidman]] as Miss Martha Farnsworth * [[Kirsten Dunst]] as Edwina Morrow * [[Elle Fanning]] as Alicia * [[Angourie Rice]] as Jane * [[Oona Laurence]] as Amy * Emma Howard as Emily * Addison Riecke as Marie {{div col end}}
==Production==
[[File:Madewood house.jpg|thumb|The Madewood Plantation House.]] Coppola had initially expressed an aversion to a remake, but after watching the 1971 version at the urging of production designer Anne Rose, she was left contemplating ways she could update the film.<ref name="EWTacky">{{cite web|last1=Sollosi|first1=Mary|title=The Beguiled: Sofia Coppola on how she made the remake her own|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/06/16/the-beguiled-sofia-coppola-la-film-festival/|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=June 16, 2017|accessdate=June 23, 2017}}</ref> Specifically, she became interested in showing the story from the women's point of view, as opposed to the man's.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lopez|first1=Kristen|title=In Conversation with Sofia Coppola|date=May 19, 2017|url=https://filmschoolrejects.com/interview-director-sofia-coppola-beguiled/|website=Film School Rejects|accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref> The material came to Coppola at a time when she wanted to make a more optimistic film than 2013's ''[[The Bling Ring]]'', stating that she wanted to "cleanse myself" from what she terms was "such a tacky, ugly world".<ref name="EWTacky"/>
In March 2016, it was announced that [[Elle Fanning]], [[Nicole Kidman]], and [[Kirsten Dunst]] had been cast in the film, while [[Colin Farrell]] entered talks that July.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/sofia-coppola-beguiled-remake-nicole-kidman-1201741673|title=Sofia Coppola to Write, Direct Remake of Clint Eastwood Drama 'The Beguiled'|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Justin|last=Kroll|date=March 29, 2016|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/29/sofia-coppola-remake-clint-eastwood-beguiled|title=Sofia Coppola to remake Southern Gothic drama The Beguiled for Focus|website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|first=Oliver|last=Gettell|date=March 29, 2016|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/colin-farrell-eyes-sofia-coppolas-the-beguiled-remake-1201792411/|title=Colin Farrell In Talks to Star in Sofia Coppola’s ‘Beguiled’ Remake (EXCLUSIVE)|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Justin|last=Kroll|date=July 14, 2016|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref> The music for the film was composed by the rock band [[Phoenix (band)|Phoenix]] (whose lead singer, [[Thomas Mars]], is married to Coppola).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/05/the-beguiled-phoenix-score-sofia-coppola-1201814725/|title=‘The Beguiled’: French Rockers Phoenix Providing Score for Sofia Coppola’s Latest Period Piece|website=[[IndieWire]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Kate|last=Erbland|date=May 10, 2017|accessdate=May 14, 2017}}</ref> Two popular Civil War ballads, "[[Lorena (song)|Lorena]]" and "[[Aura Lea]]", were used in the film, in addition to [[Stephen Foster]]'s "[[List of songs by Stephen Foster|Virginia Belle]]".<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.soundtrackmania.net/the-beguiled-soundtrack.html|author=soundtrackmania| title=The Beguiled Soundtrack|work=Soundtrack Mania| date=June 30, 2017|access-date=November 29, 2017}}</ref> Most of the costumes in the film were designed by Stacey Battat, who used the costume and fabric archives of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] to gain inspiration for contemporary fashion.<ref name="Booth Moore">{{cite article| url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/story-behind-sweet-sinister-costumes-sofia-coppola-s-beguiled-1014043| title=The Story Behind the Sweet (and Sinister) Costumes in Sofia Coppola's 'The Beguiled'| first=Booth |last=Moore| publisher= [[Prometheus Global Media]] |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]| date=June 15, 2017| access-date=November 29, 2017}}</ref> Corsets were made for each actress, while for historical accuracy only cotton fabric was used, which was in turn either [[stone washing|stone washed]] or enzyme washed to weather the fabrics and make them look worn in.<ref name="Booth Moore"/>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on October 31, 2016 and concluded on December 7, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BMPmMAVgBvE/|title=#thebeguiledmovie began filming today... Happy Halloween!|publisher=[[Instagram]]|first=Elle|last=Fanning|date=October 31, 2016|accessdate=October 31, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/12/the-beguiled-photo-kirsten-dunst-elle-fanning-last-day-sofia-coppola-set-1201755943/|title=‘The Beguiled’: Kirsten Dunst Shares Photo With Elle Fanning From Last Day on Sofia Coppola’s Set|website=[[IndieWire]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Liz|last=Calvaro|date=December 8, 2016|accessdate=December 8, 2016}}</ref> Exterior scenes were shot on the grounds of the [[Madewood Plantation House]], near [[Napoleonville, Louisiana]].<ref name="observerhouseisactually">{{cite news|last1=Halberg|first1=Morgan|title=‘The Beguiled’ House Is Actually a Charming Bed and Breakfast|url=http://observer.com/2017/06/the-beguiled-sofia-coppola-madewood-plantation-house/|accessdate=July 8, 2017|work=[[The New York Observer]]|date=June 29, 2017}}</ref> Interiors were filmed in actress [[Jennifer Coolidge]]'s house in New Orleans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/06/the-beguiled-sofia-coppola-interview.html|work=Vulture|title=How Sofia Coppola Reclaimed The Beguiled for Women (and Gay Men)|last=Buchanan|first=Kyle|publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Media]]|date=June 14, 2017|accessdate=July 9, 2017}}</ref>
==Release== The film had its world premiere at the [[2017 Cannes Film Festival]];<ref name="Nicole Kidman at The Beguiled World Premiere in Cannes"/> Coppola won the [[Best Director Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Director Award]],<ref name="All the Awards at the 70th Cannes Film Festival">{{cite web|url=http://www.ikonlondonmagazine.com/all-the-awards-at-the-70th-cannes-film-festival/ | title= All the Awards at the 70th Cannes Film Festival | work=Ikon London Magazine | last1 = Orlova-Alvarez | first1 = Tamara| last2 = Alvarez | first2 = Joe | date=May 29, 2017 | accessdate=February 23, 2018}}</ref> making her the second woman to ever win in that category, 56 years after the first female director won.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/cannes-film-festival-2017-lineup-full-list-official-selection-1202068596/|title=Cannes Lineup: Todd Haynes, Sofia Coppola, Noah Baumbach, ‘Twin Peaks’|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first1=Nancy|last1=Tartaglione|first2=Greg|last2=Evans|date=April 13, 2017|accessdate=April 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="pdf"/> The film began a [[limited release]] on June 23, 2017, before expanding to a [[wide release]] on June 30, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/focus-to-release-the-beguiled-in-june-2017/5110943.article?blocktitle=LATEST-FILM-NEWS-HEADLINES&contentID=44435|title=Focus to release 'The Beguiled' in June 2017|website=Screen Daily|publisher=[[Screen International]]|first=Jermey|last=Kay|date=November 2, 2016|accessdate=November 2, 2016}}</ref>
===Box office=== ''The Beguiled'' grossed $10.6 million in the United States and Canada and $16.1 million in other territories for a total of $26.7 million.<ref name=BOM/>
In the film's limited opening weekend, it made $240,545 from four theaters (a per-theater gross of $60,136), finishing 20th at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/transformers-the-last-knight-opening-weekend-box-office-1202118976/|title=Why ‘Transformers’ Is Screaming For Reboot After $69M Start; ‘Wonder Woman’ & ‘Cars 3’ Fight Over 2nd Place|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|accessdate=August 27, 2018|date=June 25, 2017}}</ref> In its wide opening, it made $3.2 million from 674 theaters (an average of $4,694), finishing 8th at the box office.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/despicable-me-3-baby-driver-the-house-july-4th-weekend-box-office-independence-day-1202122599/|title='Despicable Me 3’ Now At $75M+; ‘Baby Driver’ Booms To $30M As ‘The House’ Goes Broke With $9M – July 4th Weekend B.O.|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|accessdate=August 27, 2018|date=July 2, 2017}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 78% based on 281 reviews, with an average rating of 7.2/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''The Beguiled'' adds just enough extra depth to its source material to set itself apart, and director Sofia Coppola's restrained touch is enlivened by strong performances from the cast."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_beguiled |title=The Beguiled (2017) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|accessdate=August 28, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 77 out of 100, based on 45 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-beguiled |title=The Beguiled Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref>
David Ehrlich of [[IndieWire]] gave the film an "A−", saying, "Coppola's film is told with surgical precision and savage grace."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/05/the-beguiled-review-sofia-coppola-nicole-kidman-kirsten-dunst-colin-farrell-cannes-2017-1201831226/|title='The Beguiled' Review: Nicole Kidman and Kirsten Dunst Subvert Male Fantasies in Sofia Coppola’s Sensational Southern Potboiler|work=[[IndieWire]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=David|last=Ehrlich|date=May 24, 2017|accessdate=May 26, 2017}}</ref> Todd McCarthy of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' stated: "Other than to place slightly more emphasis on the female empowerment angle...it's hard to detect a strong raison d'etre behind Sofia Coppola's slow-to-develop melodrama."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/beguiled-review-1007101|title='The Beguiled': Film Review|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|first=Todd|last=McCarthy|date=May 24, 2017|accessdate=May 26, 2017}}</ref>
==Allegations of whitewashing== The 1966 novel had a black female slave as a supporting character, whom director Sofia Coppola removed from the film, and for a biracial character from the novel, she cast white actress [[Kirsten Dunst]]. ''[[The Guardian]]'' said Coppola was criticized for engaging in [[whitewashing in film|whitewashing]], to which the director said she made the changes so as "not [to] brush over such an important topic in a light way," and that "[y]oung girls watch my films and this was not the depiction of an African American character I would want to show them."<ref>Whitewashing citations: * {{cite news | last=Lodge | first=Guy | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/jul/02/sofia-coppola-beguiled-i-never-felt-i-had-to-fit-into-the-majority-view-interview | title=Sofia Coppola: 'I never felt I had to fit into the majority view' | work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian News and Media]] | date=July 2, 2017 | accessdate=July 3, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Rao | first=Sonia | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/06/22/sofia-coppolas-the-beguiled-criticized-for-leaving-out-a-slave-narrative-from-the-confederate-south/ | title=Sofia Coppola’s 'The Beguiled' criticized for leaving out a slave narrative from the Confederate South | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=June 22, 2017 |publisher=The Washington Post Company |accessdate=August 27, 2018}} * {{cite magazine | last=Brody | first=Richard | url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/the-beguiled-sofia-coppolas-dubiously-abstract-vision-of-the-civil-war | title='The Beguiled': Sofia Coppola’s Dubiously Abstract Vision of the Civil War | magazine=[[The New Yorker]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] | date=June 23, 2017 | accessdate=July 3, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Atad | first=Corey | url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2017/06/sofia_coppola_s_whitewashed_new_movie_the_beguiled.html | title=Lost in Adaptation | work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |publisher=[[The Slate Group]] | date=June 20, 2017 | accessdate=July 2, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Madison III | first=Ira | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/sofia-coppolas-the-beguiled-and-what-we-expect-from-white-directors | title=Sofia Coppola’s ‘The Beguiled’ Controversy and What We Expect From White Directors | work=[[The Daily Beast]] |publisher=The Daily Beast Company | date=June 24, 2017 | accessdate=July 3, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Kang | first=Inkoo | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/3021638/lost-in-translation-is-an-insufferable-racist-mess-why-would-we-expect-the-beguiled-to-be-any-different/ | title=Lost In Translation Is An Insufferable, Racist Mess — Why Would We Expect The Beguiled To Be Any Different? | work=[[MTV News]] |publisher=[[MTV]] | date=June 20, 2017 | accessdate=July 3, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Monagle | first=Matthew | url=https://filmschoolrejects.com/sofia-coppola-whitewashing-controversy-beguiled/ | title=On Sofia Coppola and the Whitewashing Controversy of 'The Beguiled' | work=[[Film School Rejects]] | date=June 23, 2017 | accessdate=July 3, 2017 }} * {{cite news | last=Rose | first=Steve | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/jul/10/beguiled-how-hollywood-whitewashing-us-civil-war-sofia-coppola | title=The Beguiled: how Hollywood is whitewashing the US civil war | work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian News and Media]] | date=July 10, 2017 | accessdate=July 10, 2017 }} </ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox Historic Site | name = The Falcon| native_name = | image = Falcon 2.jpg| image_size = 300px| caption = The Falcon from the northeast| locmapin = Cheshire| map_width = 180| map_caption = Location in Cheshire | coordinates = {{coord|53.1883|-2.8910|scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Chester]], [[Cheshire]], England| area = | elevation = | formed = | founded = | built = c. 1200| built_for = | demolished = | rebuilt = 13th century
16th–17th century| restored = 1643, c. 1879, c. 1886, 1979–82| restored_by = [[John Douglas (architect)|John Douglas]] (c. 1879),
[[George Enoch Grayson|Grayson]] and [[Edward Ould|Ould]] (1886)| architect = | architecture = [[Timber framing]]| visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = | designation1 = Grade I| designation1_offname = No.6 Falcon Inn | designation1_type = | designation1_criteria = | designation1_date = 28 July 1955| delisted1_date = | designation1_parent = | designation1_number = | designation1_free1name = | designation1_free1value = | designation1_free2name = | designation1_free2value = | designation1_free3name = | designation1_free3value = }} '''The Falcon''' is a [[public house]] in [[Chester]], [[Cheshire]], England. It stands on the west side of Lower Bridge Street at its junction with Grosvenor Road. The Falcon is recorded in the [[National Heritage List for England]] as a designated Grade I [[Listed building#England and Wales|listed building]].{{NHLE |num= 1376292|desc= Falcon Inn, Chester|accessdate= 11 April 2015|mode=cs2|ps=none}} The building formerly incorporated part of [[Chester Rows]], but it was the first building to have its portion of the row enclosed in the 17th century. ==History== The building originated as a house in about 1200 and was later extended to the south along Lower Bridge Street, with a great hall running parallel to the street. During the 13th century it was rebuilt to incorporate its portion of the row. It was rebuilt again during the late 16th and early 17th centuries. The house was bought in 1602 by [[Sir Richard Grosvenor, 1st Baronet|Sir Richard Grosvenor]] who extensively altered it some 40 years later to make it his [[Townhouse|town house]]. During the [[English Civil War|Civil War]] he moved his family here from his country home, [[Eaton Hall, Cheshire|Eaton Hall]]. In 1643 Sir Richard petitioned the City Assembly for leave to enlarge his house by enclosing the portion of the row which passed through his property. This was successful and it set a precedent for other residents of Lower Bridge Street to enclose their portion of the rows, or to build new structures which did not incorporate the rows.{{Citation | url = http://www.virtualchester.org/view/view_location.php?id=19 | title = The Falcon | accessdate = 17 July 2009| publisher = Chester City Council}} In the late 18th century the building ceased to be the town house of the Grosvenor family. It continued to be owned by them, and between 1778 and 1878 it was licensed as ''The Falcon Inn''. In about 1879 alterations were made by [[John Douglas (architect)|John Douglas]]. At this time it was known as ''The Falcon Cocoa House''{{Citation | last =Hubbard | first =Edward | authorlink = Edward Hubbard | title =The Work of John Douglas |edition= | publisher =[[The Victorian Society]] | year =1991 | location =London | page = 250| isbn =0-901657-16-6 }} and it was re-opened as a [[Temperance movement|temperance house]]. In 1886 [[George Enoch Grayson|Grayson]] and [[Edward Ould|Ould]] carried out a restoration.{{Citation | last = Hartwell | first = Clare |last2 = Hyde | first2 = Matthew |last3 = Hubbard | first3 = Edward | author3-link=Edward Hubbard | last4 =Pevsner | first4 =Nikolaus | author4-link =Nikolaus Pevsner | series= The Buildings of England| title = Cheshire |edition= | publisher =[[Yale University Press]]| year =2011| origyear=1971| location =New Haven and London| page = 262| url = | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-300-17043-6 }} By the 1970s the building had become virtually derelict.{{Citation | last = Morriss| first = Richard| author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | publication-date = | date = | year = 1993| title = The Buildings of Chester| edition = | volume = | series = | publication-place = Dover| place = | publisher = Alan Sutton| pages = | page = 23| id = | isbn = 0-7509-0255-8| doi = | oclc = | url = | accessdate =}} In 1979 the Falcon Trust was established, and the building was donated to the trust by the [[Grosvenor Group|Grosvenor Estate]]. Between 1979 and 1982 the building was restored and in 1983 it won a [[Europa Nostra]] award. The building was donated to the Falcon Trust by the [[Grosvenor Group|Grosvenor Estate]], and was reopened by the [[Gerald Grosvenor, 6th Duke of Westminster|Duke of Westminster]] in May 1992.{{Citation |editor1-last= Langtree|editor1-first= Stephen|editor2-last= Comyns|editor2-first= Alan| year = 2001| title = 2000 Years of Building: Chester's Architectural Legacy| publication-place = Chester| place = | publisher = Chester Civic Trust| pages = 64–65| page = | format = | id = | isbn = 0-9540152-0-7}} ==Architecture== ===Exterior=== [[File:Falconinn.jpg|200px|thumb|The Falcon from the east]] [[File:Falcon Inn, Chester.jpg|200px|thumb|The Falcon from the north]] [[File:The Falcon inn, Chester.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''The Falcon'', by [[Edward Harrison Compton]], before 1916]] The east face of The Falcon is on Lower Bridge Street and the north face on Grosvenor Road. The east face has two storeys on a [[sandstone]] plinth with two [[gable]]s. Most of the sandstone is [[Stucco|rendered]]. To the left is a staircase of nine steps leading from the street to the lower storey, which is the level of the enclosed row. The lower storey has [[Close studding|close timber studding]] and an eleven-light leaded window. Above this is a row of twelve [[quatrefoil]] panels which slope slightly outwards over which is a continuous 34-light leaded window. The two gables are carried on brackets which curve outwards, and have herringbone [[strut]]s, [[Molding (decorative)|moulded]] [[bargeboard]]s and shaped [[finial]]s. The north face give the appearance of two buildings. The older part is to the left (east) and the newer right (west) part was possibly added by Sir Richard Grosvenor in 1626. The eastern portion is a continuation of the east front. The street level and the lower storey are in sandstone, partly rendered, some of which has been replaced by brick. The upper storey has a window of six lights, which are continuous with those on the east face and two quatrefoils above. To the right of these is timber framing and a window. Above is a grey slate roof and a lateral shaped chimney in brick. The western portion has a rendered [[plinth]] with timber framing above. On the lower storey is a door and two windows, one with seven lights and the other with four. The upper storey has similar windows, plus a one-light window over the door. ===Interior=== The medieval undercroft is used as the beer cellar. It was originally a single three-bay chamber but has been divided by a [[Brick|brick wall]] into a two-bay north chamber and a single-bay south chamber. In the cellar are two octagonal stone [[Pier (architecture)|piers]] and a massive central east-west oak beam. On the level of the row is a room along the east side, which is the enclosed portion of the row, and two rooms behind, with a further room in the west wing. ==See also== {{Portal|Cheshire}} *[[Grade I listed buildings in Cheshire West and Chester]] ==References== {{Commons category|The Falcon Inn, Chester}} {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Falcon, Chester}} [[Category:Grade I listed buildings in Chester]] [[Category:Pubs in Chester]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Timber framed buildings in Cheshire]] [[Category:Grade I listed pubs in England]]

{{Infobox artwork/wikidata|onlysourced=yes}} '''''The Source''''' ({{lang-fr|'''La Source'''}}) is an [[oil painting]] on [[canvas]] by French [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical]] painter [[Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres]]. The work was begun in [[Florence]] around 1820 and not completed until 1856, in [[Paris]].<ref name="Musée d'Orsay">{{cite web |url=http://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/collections/catalogue-des-oeuvres/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=525 |title=La Source |publisher=[[Musée d'Orsay]] |accessdate=2 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Company2003">{{cite book |author=Houghton Mifflin Company |title=The Houghton Mifflin dictionary of biography |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rySr84jox_AC&pg=PA782 |year=2003 |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] |isbn=978-0-618-25210-7 |pages=782-}}</ref> When Ingres completed ''The Source'', he was seventy-six years old,<ref name="Arnheim2004">{{cite book|author=Arnheim, Rudolf |title=Art and visual perception: a psychology of the creative eye |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9RktoatXGQ0C&pg=PA152 |year=2004 |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |isbn=978-0-520-24383-5 |page=152}}</ref> already famous,<ref name="Magi1999">{{cite book |author=Magi, Giovanna |title=Grand Louvre and the Musee D'Orsay |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4VsrAyUEgAC&pg=PA91 |year=1999 |publisher=Casa Editrice Bonechi |isbn=978-88-7009-780-1 |page=91}}</ref> and president of the [[École des Beaux-Arts]].<ref name="Baguley2000"/> The pose of the nude may be compared with that of another by Ingres, the ''[[Venus Anadyomene]]'' (1848),<ref name="Geist1988">{{cite book |author=Geist, Sidney |title=Interpreting Cézanne |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7cse0EiksSkC&pg=PA93 |year=1988 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |isbn=978-0-674-45955-7 |page=93}}</ref> and is a reimagination of the [[Aphrodite of Cnidus]] or ''Venus Pudica''.<ref name="Baguley2000">{{cite book |author=Baguley, David |title=Napoleon III and his regime: an extravaganza |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=acgxXxume2sC&pg=PA317 |year=2000 |publisher=[[LSU Press]] |isbn=978-0-8071-2624-0 |pages=317–}}</ref> Two of Ingres' students, painters [[Paul Balze]] and [[Alexandre Desgoffe]], helped to create the background and water jar.<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/>
==Description== The painting depicts a [[Depictions of nudity|nude]] standing upright between an opening in the rocks and holding in her hands a [[Pitcher (container)|pitcher]], from which water flows. She thus represents a [[Source (hydrology)|water source]] or [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]] which, in [[Classics|classical literature]], is sacred to the [[Muses]] and a source of poetic inspiration.<ref name="Symbols">{{cite book |title=A dictionary of literary symbols |author=Ferber, Michael |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-521-87042-9 |pages=75ff, 80f, 104f, 170ff}}</ref> She stands between two flowers, with their "vulnerability to males who wish to pluck them",<ref name="Symbols"/> and is framed by [[ivy]], plant of [[Dionysus]] the god of disorder, regeneration, and ecstasy.<ref name="Symbols"/> The water she pours out separates her from the viewer, as rivers mark boundaries of which the crossing is symbolically important.<ref name="Symbols"/> [[File:La Source Fountain.JPG|thumb|right|The marble statue based on ''The Source (Ingres)''. This exhibit was specially commissioned by [[Dorabji Tata]] and presented to the [[Prince of Wales Museum]], [[Mumbai]] where it is on display.]]
==Theme== [[Art historians]] Frances Fowle and Richard Thomson suggest that there is a "symbolic unity of woman and nature" in ''The Source'', where the flowering plants and water serve as a background which Ingres fills with woman's "secondary attributes".<ref name="FowleThomson2003">{{cite book |author1=Fowle, Francis |author2=Thomson, Richard |title=Soil and stone: impressionism, urbanism, environment |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udT3p5pusY8C&pg=PA23 |year=2003 |publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|isbn=978-0-7546-3685-4 |page=23}}</ref>
==Reception== The first exhibition of ''The Source'' was in 1856, the year it was completed.<ref name="Stoddart1990">{{cite book |author=Stoddart, David Michael |title=The scented ape: the biology and culture of human odour |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NYBux6MdmbIC&pg=PA131 |year=1990 |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |isbn=978-0-521-39561-8 |page=131}}</ref> The painting was received enthusiastically.<ref name="Magi1999"/> [[Tanneguy Duchâtel|Duchâtel]] acquired the painting in 1857 for a sum of 25,000 francs. The state assumed title to the painting in 1878 and it passed to the [[Musée du Louvre]]. In 1986 it was transferred to the [[Musée d'Orsay]].<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/> The painting has been frequently exhibited and widely published.<ref name="Musée d'Orsay"/><ref name="Fried1998">{{cite book |author=Fried, Michael |title=Manet's modernism, or, The face of painting in the 1860s |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aV9bPK-vE6cC&pg=PA518 |year=1998 |publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] |isbn=978-0-226-26217-8 |page=518}}</ref>
Haldane Macfall in ''A History of Painting: The French Genius'' describes ''The Source'' as Ingres' "superb nude by which he is chiefly known".<ref name="Macfall2004">{{cite book |author=Macfall, Haldane |title=A History of Painting: The French Genius (vol. 6) |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UWrGyKyc60oC&pg=PA275 |date=August 2004 |publisher=[[Kessinger Publishing]] |isbn=978-1-4179-4511-5 |page=275}}</ref> [[Kenneth Clark]] in his book ''Feminine Beauty'' observed how ''The Source'' has been described as "the most beautiful figure in French painting."<ref name="Strobel1999">{{cite book |author=Henry A. Strobel |title=Reflections: personal essays |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6wac58KGK1sC&pg=PA62 |year=1999 |publisher=Henry Strobel Publisher |isbn=978-1-892210-01-2|page=62}}</ref> [[Walter Friedländer]] in ''David to Delacroix'' referred to ''The Source'' simply as the most famous of Ingres' paintings.<ref name="Friedlaender1952">{{cite book|author=[[Walter Friedländer|Friedländer, Walter F.]] |title=David to Delacroix |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rhm0pV_t-Z0C&pg=PA87 |year=1952 |publisher=[[Harvard University Press]] |isbn=978-0-674-19401-4 |page=87}}</ref>
The model for the painting was the young daughter of Ingres' [[concierge]].<ref name="Macfall2004"/> In his ''[[Confessions of a Young Man]]'', Irish novelist [[George Moore (novelist)|George Moore]] wrote, with relation to the [[Art and morality|morality of artistic production]], "What care I that the virtue of some sixteen-year-old maid was the price for Ingres' ''La Source''? That the model died of drink and disease in the hospital is nothing when compared with the essential that I should have ''La Source'', that exquisite dream of innocence."<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.jstor.org/pss/430264 |title=The Morality of Artistic Production |author=Barrett, Cyril |journal=[[The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism]] |publisher=[[Wiley-Blackwell]] |year=1982 |volume=41 |number=2 |pages=137–144}}</ref>

{{Infobox book | name = Theory and History | image = Theory and History, Front Cover, Ludwig von Mises.jpg | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Ludwig von Mises]]
Preface by [[Murray N. Rothbard]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subjects = [[Philosophy]], [[Methodology]], [[History]], [[Economics]] | publisher = [[Yale University Press]], [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] | pub_date = 1957 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 384 | isbn = 978-0865975699 | oclc = 167149 }} '''''Theory and History: An Interpretation of Social and Economic Evolution''''' is a treatise by [[Austrian School|Austrian school]] economist and philosopher [[Ludwig von Mises]]. It can be thought of as a continuation in the development of the Misesian system of social science. In particular, it provides further [[epistemology|epistemological]] support for his earlier works, esp. [[Human Action]]. Most notably, Mises elaborates on [[methodological dualism]], develops the concept of [[thymology]] – a historical branch of the sciences of human action – and presents his critique of Marxist [[Dialectical materialism|materialism]]. Furthermore, Mises puts forward a theory of knowledge and value. He later explores and critically analyzes paradigms of thought like [[determinism]], [[materialism]], [[dialectic materialism]], [[historicism]], [[scientism]], [[positivism]], [[behaviorism]] and [[psychology]]. He argues that these schools of thought – some politically motivated,Mises. (1957). ''Theory and history'', pp. 26, 134. others blinded by dogmatism''id''. pp. 30, 77, 111, 247. – have committed epistemological and methodological blunders and are not conducive to a scientific understanding of human behavior. Economist [[Murray Rothbard]] considered ''Theory and History'' to be Mises's most overlooked work.''id''. pp. xi-xix == Synopsis == Mises presents the book in four parts. '''Introduction and Part One – Value:''' The first part sets the overall theme of the book with Mises introducing the concept of [[methodological dualism]]. He then expounds a theory of value that is central throughout. Regarding his view on science – as systematic body of knowledge, of both natural and social phenomena – as a means to successful action in the world, Mises argues that in order to properly understand human behavior we must attribute – as a methodological resort – [[Volition (psychology)|volition]] and [[Teleology|purpose]] to human behaviour. Mises considers this the epistemological and methodological basis of the sciences of human action. The branch that deals with the logical implications of action as such is called [[praxeology]]. '''Part Two – Determinism and Materialism:''' In the second part, Mises weighs in on the [[free will]] vs. [[determinism]] controversy and comments that the long historical debates did little to settle the problems at hand. He argues that while the natural sciences, in discovering scientific laws, must presuppose a strict regularity in the occurrence of causes and effects, i.e. determinism, such a presupposition cannot be held in the case of human action. He argues further that the social sciences must take [[thought]]s, [[idea]]s, and [[value judgment|judgments of value]] as ultimately given in the analysis of human action. Our ignorance of the origins and causes of these phenomena, Mises argues, forces us – at least for the time being – to adopt a dualistic approach. He contends that attempts to find the origins and causes of these phenomena are vain, as is the task of all varieties of materialism.''id''. p. 69. Mises then turns his attention to the doctrine of materialism, more specifically, that of Marxist dialectical materialism. '''Part Three – Epistemological Problems of History:''' The third part deals with the logical and epistemological problems of historical analysis. Mises explains the individualistic character of historical human events. He argues that the historian must ultimately face – when tracing back the causal factors behind past human action – a point at which no further reduction is possible, i.e. the ideas and actions of individuals. This, he claims, is the "ultimate given of history".''id''. pp. 183–8. In spite of the individuality of historical events, Mises still insists there are general laws of human behaviour but that they are praxeological laws, i.e. [[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]], not historical laws, i.e. [[A priori and a posteriori|a posteriori]]. However, [[historicism]], according to Mises, claimed there were no general laws – especially economic laws – of human behavior. Mises then enters into a critique of historicism. Mises also addresses the challenges of scientism in the context of social science, namely the application of positivism and behaviorism in the realm of human action. However, more noteworthy is Mises's presentation of [[thymology]], a historical branch of the sciences of human action. Mises argues that thymology is what everybody resorts to when trying to [[Verstehen|''understand'']] and anticipate the historical and future actions of their fellow men, and is particularly useful to the historian. He then expounds the scope of thymology and its relation to praxeology. '''Part Four – The Course of History:''' In the final part of his treatise, Mises dissects and critiques various speculations and interpretations of history, including a common interpretation of modern [[Western culture|Western civilization]]. He also comments on his observation regarding society's move away from [[classical liberalism]], freedom, and capitalism towards socialism and totalitarianism. Moreover, Mises notes the rising ideology of wealth and income equality and speculates on its origins. He argues that rising anti-capitalistic ideology is fostering a present trend toward the impoverishment of society. He criticizes the notion of society's inevitable "trend toward progress",''id''. pp. 367-70. and argues that the evolution of society and civilization is predicated – not on an automatic and inevitable path – but on the underlying ideology which can, at any time, change. To this point, Mises closes with some remarks on the uncertainty of the future and the neglect of ideological factors that can give rise to civilization but also stamp it out. == See also == * [[Praxeology]], the study of human action * ''[[Human Action]]'' * [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://mises.org/library/theory-and-history-interpretation-social-and-economic-evolution Book page] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [https://mises.org/quotes.aspx?action=source&Source=Theory%20and%20History Quotes from the book] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [https://mises.org/system/tdf/Theory%20and%20History%20An%20Interpretation%20of%20Social%20and%20Economic%20Evolution_1.pdf?file=1&type=document The book as PDF] at [https://www.mises.org/ Ludwig von Mises Institute] * [http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/1464 The book as HTML] at [http://oll.libertyfund.org// Online Library of Liberty] * [https://mises.org/library/theory-and-history-6 Audiobook] – read by [[John Pruden]] {{Ludwig von Mises}} [[Category:1957 books]] [[Category:Books by Ludwig von Mises]] [[Category:Classical liberalism]] [[Category:Contemporary philosophical literature]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Philosophy of social science]]

{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=May 2010}} {{advert|date=May 2010}} }}
{{Thoreauviana |expanded=Core}} The '''Thoreau Society''' is a [[literary society]] devoted to the works of [[Henry David Thoreau]], it is based in [[Concord, Massachusetts|Concord]], [[Massachusetts]], USA. Established in 1941, it has long contributed to the dissemination of knowledge about Henry David Thoreau by collecting books, manuscripts, and artifacts relating to Thoreau and his contemporaries, by encouraging the use of its collections, and by publishing articles in two Society periodicals.
The Thoreau Society archives are housed at the Walden Woods Project's Thoreau Institute Library in [[Lincoln, Massachusetts]]. This repository includes the collections of Walter Harding and Raymond Adams, two of the foremost authorities on Thoreau and founders of the Thoreau Society; and those of [[Roland W. Robbins]], who uncovered Thoreau's Walden house site.
== Mission== *To stimulate interest in and foster education about Thoreau's life, works, and philosophy and his place in his world and ours, *To encourage research on Thoreau's life and writings, *To act as a repository for Thoreauviana and material relevant to Thoreau, *And to advocate for the preservation of Thoreau Country.
== Members==
Thoreau Society members represent a wide range of professions, interests, and hometowns across the United States and around the [[world]]. They are connected by the conviction that Henry Thoreau had important things to say and crucial questions to ask that are just as significant in our time as in his.
Through its programs, publications and projects, The Thoreau Society is committed to exploring Thoreau's observations on living with self, society and nature, and encouraging people to think about how they live their own lives.
==Activities==
===Annual Gathering=== Four days of indoor and outdoor sessions and excursions in and around Concord focused on a different theme each year. The Thursday–Sunday program is scheduled in early July.
===Educational Programs=== Lectures, classes, and performances in Thoreau's hometown of Concord, often in collaboration with other historical, literary, environmental and educational organizations. An educational DVD, "Life With Principle," is available for high school and adult audiences with a full accompanying curriculum and related workshops.
=== Excursions=== [[Image:Henley Library, Thoreau Society, Lincoln MA.jpg|thumb|right|242px|<center>Henley Library at the Thoreau Institute</center>]] Trips to places associated with Thoreau, from half-day hikes to multi-day outings. Past locations have included [[Mt. Katahdin]], [[Cape Cod]], [[Harpers Ferry]], Mt. Monadnock and Concord sites such as [[Egg Rock]], Fairhaven Bay, Gowing's Swamp and Sleepy Hollow Cemetery.
=== Presentations === At academic conferences (both the [[Modern Language Association]] and the [[American Literature Association]] have two annual sessions at their conferences each devoted to Thoreau) and workshops for educators.
=== Projects and Events=== Coordinated by Society members, these take place in communities across the country and worldwide, on a variety of topics, and are posted on the Society's website.
== Publications ==
=== ''Thoreau Society Bulletin'' === A quarterly publication with Society news, additions to the Thoreau bibliography, and short articles on Thoreau and related topics. Edited by Mark Gallagher.
=== ''Concord Saunterer'' === An annual scholarly and popular journal with two hundred pages of in-depth essays on Thoreau, his times and his contemporaries, and his influence today. Edited by John J. Kucich.
=== Books === The Society publishes original Thoreau-related books and reprints of selected hard-to-find titles about Thoreau.
=== The Collections === The Thoreau Society owns several important collections, including the papers of Walter Harding, Raymond Adams, and Roland Robbins, which are housed at the Thoreau Institute at Walden Woods. This research facility, founded through a collaboration between the Walden Woods Project and The Thoreau Society, is managed by the Walden Woods Project.
== External links== *[http://www.thoreausociety.org Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100505210735/http://www.walden.org/Library/The_Library_Collections The Thoreau Society Collections at the Thoreau Institute at Walden Woods]
{{Henry David Thoreau| state=expanded}}

{{italic title}} '''''Uz Maršala Tita''''' ({{lang-sh|Uz Maršala Tita}}, {{lang-en|With Marshall Tito}}) is a [[Yugoslav Partisan]] anthem about Marshal and president of [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] [[Josip Broz Tito]], written by [[Vladimir Nazor]] and composed by [[Oskar Danon]].http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/world/text.php?vest=118576 During the [[World War II in Yugoslavia]], the [[Ustaše]] regime in German-sponsored [[Independent State of Croatia]] (NDH) claimed origins from [[Goths]] (i.e., [[Ostrogoths]], see also [[Origin hypotheses of the Croats|theories about origin of Croats]]), instead of [[Slavic peoples|Slavs]],[[Noel Malcolm]], Bosnia: A Short History (1994), Chapter 1 which would make them "[[Aryan race|Aryans]]", and closer to the [[Nazism|Nazi]] regime. The middle stanza of this song addresses that by outright refutal of Gothic theory and by reaffirming the Slavic origins of all [[South Slavs]]. ==Lyrics== {| ![[Serbo-Croatian language|Serbo-Croatian Latin]]||Literal English translation||English translation||[[Serbo-Croatian]] Cyrillic |- | Uz maršala Tita, junačkoga sina
nas neće ni pakao smest'.
Mi dižemo čelo, mi kročimo smjelo
i čvrsto stiskamo pest. Rod prastari svi smo, a Goti mi nismo,
Slavenstva smo drevnoga čest.
Ko drukčije kaže, kleveće i laže,
Našu će osjetit' pest. Sve prste na ruci u jadu i muci
Partizanska stvorila je svijest.
Pa sad kad i treba, do Sunca do neba
Visoko mi dižemo pest. | With Marshall Tito, the heroic son
not even Hell shall stop us.
We raise our foreheads, we walk boldly
and clench our fists hard. Of an ancient kindred we are, but Goths we are not
Part of ancient Slavdom are we.
Whoever says otherwise slanders and lies,
will feel our fist. All the fingers upon our hands, through misery and suffering
The Partisans awareness has created.
And now when we should, to the sun, to the sky,
We raise our fists high. | With great Marshall Tito, our land's bravest hero,
We'll be even stronger than [[Hell]]!
We raise our heads bravely, and not hung down gravely,
And clench our fists hard as well. We're from an ancient tribe, but [[Goths]] we don't ascribe,
As we're children of ancient [[Slavs]].
He who says otherwise merely slanders and lies,
And surely will face our wrath. All fingers on our hands will fight to save our lands,
As the [[Yugoslav Partisans|partisans]] are always spry.
When we die we don't cry to the sun or the sky,
We just raise our fists on high. | Уз маршала Tита, јуначкога сина
Нас неће ни пакао смест'.
Ми дижемо чело, ми крочимо смјело
И чврсто стискамо пест' Род прастари сви смо, а Готи ми нисмо
Славенства смо древнога чест.
Ко друкчије каже, клевеће и лаже
Нашу ће осjетит' пест. Све прсте на руци у јаду и муци
Партизанска створила је свијест.
Па сад кад и треба, до сунца до неба
Високо ми дижемо пест.
|} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Uz Marsala Tita}} [[Category:Yugoslav Partisan songs]] [[Category:Songs of World War II]] [[Category:Pan-Slavism]] [[Category:Propaganda in Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Propaganda songs]] [[Category:Songs about Europe]] [[Category:Songs about politicians]] [[Category:Songs about military officers]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Josip Broz Tito]] [[Category:1940s songs]] [[Category:Year of song unknown]] [[Category:Songwriter unknown]]

'''''Voorslag''''' ('''''Whiplash''''') was a literary journal published in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]] in 1926 and 1927.<ref name="eblw">{{cite book|author1=Eugene Benson|author2=L.W. Conolly|title=Encyclopedia of Post-Colonial Literatures in English|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nGfMAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA904|accessdate=19 February 2017|date=30 November 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-46848-5|page=904}}</ref> It was the first modern small magazine in South Africa and was subtitled "A Magazine of South African Life and Art".<ref name="eblw"/> The magazine was founded by [[Roy Campbell (poet)|Roy Campbell]] and [[William Plomer]]; [[Laurens van der Post]] was invited to become its [[Afrikaans]] correspondent. Campbell served as the publication's editor for three issues before resigning due to interference from his proprietor, [[Lewis Reynolds]]; Reynolds discouraged ''Voorslag'''s criticism of the colonial system.
==References== {{Reflist}} * Peter F. Alexander. ''William Plomer: A Biography'' (Oxford Lives, 1991) * Andrew Edward Van der Vlies, ''South African textual cultures: white, black, read all over'', [[Manchester University Press]], 2007, {{ISBN|0-7190-7614-5}} * [[Joseph Pearce]], ''Unafraid of Virginia Woolf'' (ISI Books, Wilmington, Delaware: 2004), pp. 81-85
[[Category:Art magazines]] [[Category:Defunct literary magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of South Africa]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1926]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1927]] [[Category:Media in Durban]] [[Category:South African magazines]]
